comment.author: 30884978@N00
comment._content: The kid clearly moved instead of staying still for the photo!

comment.author: 18007377@N08
comment._content: This has happened I think to all of us trying to capture children. They move and you end up with an image much like this one.  What an honor it is to view these images from the 1800's.  So impressed with the quality and integrity of the images taken over a hundred years ago.

comment.author: 31385389@N08
comment._content: How many of our photos will be around in a hundred year's time?

comment.author: 87914514@N00
comment._content: Hi, this photo has been mentioned in a discussion thread in the Flickr Commonsgroup, and we'd love to have this added to the group pool! -- Seen in a discussion of Flickr Commons. (?)

comment.author: 34226837@N08
comment._content: So happy I'm not the only one with a child that moves during picture's.  But even beyond that the expressions on their faces tell the story as well.

comment._content: great shot...

comment._content: i rebember those days wen life was very hard but we had love and frendship.Nick D.P.

comment._content: Wouuuuuu look the boy.

comment.author: 19711658@N07
comment._content: what place is it?¿?

comment.author: 35501648@N07
comment._content:
Little boy is so cute but clearly moved his head.  Maybe he heard something or was too little to know to hold still.  Used to have to hold still a very long time for old photos.

Look at their clothes. People used to use what they had until it wore out.  Now we call it recycling.  ;-)

comment.author: 10758109@N04
comment._content: Poor little bairns :-(  what a tough life... bet some adults couldn't hack even now living like they did back then.

comment.author: 10758109@N04
comment._content: @Fool Follet...indeed that is true re the clothes.  That is why 'well to do' clothes manage to get in to museums but the clothes of the hard everyday worker do not.  It is rare indeed to find any in a museum.  One museum i worked managed to get a very neat supply of used victorian stockings etc as they had been used to stuff a piece of furniture :-)  it was a great find.

comment.author: 35501648@N07
comment._content:
Wow Sandy that is a really interesting story! Must've been a great day! Like finding buried treasure kind of.

I agree most people today could not work like they did then or even 50 years ago.

comment._content: The young girl is barefoot and he has steel toes and heels on his boots.  Wonder if they worked in the coal mines?  Such poverty!!  Hope things got better for them.....

comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auchmithie Its in North east Scotland near Arbroath. She is wearing typical herring Quines [girls] clothes for scaling and gutting herring.
